Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CIF: Fundamental Research on Energy Efficiency and Security of RF Energy Harvesting Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
To meet the ever-growing energy need for powering numerous wireless devices in applications of smart city, precision agriculture, and public safety, energy harvesting is emerging as a promising alternative to traditional power grids and batteries. Through scavenging radio energy from the surrounding environment, the radio frequency (RF) energy harvesting device can run semi-perpetually without a battery replacement. The energy harvesting feature, however, raises unique vulnerabilities in RF energy harvesting wireless networks. The investigator identifies a radically new threat model, called malicious energy attack: the adversary energy source threatens the information security by intentionally charging specific nodes to manipulate routing paths in the network layer. This project explores the non-linearity in energy harvesting systems and investigates reinforcement learning-enabled energy attack and defense mechanisms. It aims to develop efficient and secure communications for RF energy harvesting wireless networks. The project is expected to support development of sustainable and secure wireless networks, thereby leading to a broad impact on industrial sectors relying on energy harvesting techniques. The material generated from this project will be integrated into multiple courses on computer security and wireless networks.

This project is organized around two research topics. The first topic develops offline and online optimal data transmission strategies based on a new nonlinear recursive energy harvesting model that considers the energy clamp phenomenon caused by dynamic RF environment, the nonlinear charging of the battery, and the nonlinear harvesting circuits. The second topic proposes a reinforcement learning-enabled intelligent energy attack method, where the adversary energy source can intelligently charge and control the energy level of each infected node based on the partial information of the traffic distribution in the network. Meanwhile, two defense mechanisms are developed to protect RF energy harvesting wireless networks from malicious energy attacks. In performing the above tasks, this research will build an RF energy harvesting wireless network testbed to facilitate radical breakthroughs over the practical design of models, algorithms, and protocols in forked projects.

This project is jointly funded by CISE CCF and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Achievements:

This project has yielded significant research outcomes, with 11 research papers submitted, including 8 published in prestigious journals and conferences such as IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics (TII), IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security (TIFS), IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing (TMC), IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications (TWC), and IEEE Transactions on Communications (TCOM). The remaining 3 papers are currently under review, showcasing the project's ongoing contribution to the field.

Educational Impact:

The project has made a substantial impact on education by supporting one PhD student who is set to graduate in Spring 2024. This student has demonstrated exceptional research capabilities, earning the 2023 CS Outstanding Graduate Researcher Award at the University of Alabama (UA). This accolade highlights the project's commitment to fostering the next generation of researchers and scholars. 

Industrial Collaboration:

In the industrial domain, the project has embraced a multidisciplinary approach by collaborating with civil engineering and agriculture sectors. A notable achievement is the development of RF energy harvesting powered IoT devices, providing a battery-free solution for long-term, sustainable, and scalable structural health and soil condition monitoring. This innovation addresses critical needs in infrastructure maintenance and agricultural management, demonstrating the project's practical applications and industry relevance.

Societal Outreach:

The project has made a significant impact on society through its participation in MATHCOUNT-Tuscaloosa STEM Demos in 2023 and 2024. By showcasing battery-free IoT technology to regional middle school students, the team has aimed to spark interest in computer science careers and broaden participation among students from underrepresented groups. This outreach effort aligns with the project's goal of inspiring the next generation of technologists and innovators.

In conclusion, this project has achieved notable success across research, education, industrial collaboration, and societal outreach. The project's contributions not only advance scientific knowledge but also have practical applications, educational impacts, and societal benefits, underscoring the multifaceted value of this research endeavor.

  • IoT devices powered by RF energy harvesting offer a battery-free solution for long-term, sustainable, and scalable soil condition monitoring. In this project, we address the challenges posed by low RF energy density and propose energy-efficient solutions.

    Utilizing RF energy harvesting powered IoT for precision agriculture

    Utilizing RF energy harvesting powered IoT for structural health monitoring applications
